metadata.title: Influence of meteorological factors and air pollution on the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome

abstract.original_text: Q.-W. Jiang). 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.42, 0.66), DARH (OR ¼ 0.73, 95% CI: 0.53, 1.00), and daily average wind velocity (DAWV; OR ¼ 0.81, 95% CI: 0.68, 0.96). Adjustment for the onset time of a primary case led to little change in the results. In addition, in Hebei Province, a major affected area in China, only DAWV (OR ¼ 0.38, 95% CI: 0.20, 0.72) was a significant predictor of secondary attack rate with adjustment for the onset time of primary case. In Inner Mongolia, another major affected area in China, DAWV (OR ¼ 0.50, 95% CI: 0.26, 0.94) and DHS (OR ¼ 0.27, 95% CI: 0.09, 0.81) were significant predictors of secondary attack rate with adjustment for the onset time of primary case. Conclusions: Our results suggest that the SARS outbreak was significantly associated with DAWV, and that DAAP, DARH and DHS may also have influenced the SARS outbreak to some extent. However, because of ecological fallacy and uncontrolled confounding effects that may have biased the results, the association between the SARS outbreak and these meteorological factors and air pollution deserve further investigation.
